Civil society partners will concentrate on pro-reform agenda activities focused on combating corruption and thus strengthening good governance and the democratic institutions responsible for it. Award Title: Feed the Future Bangladesh Aquaculture and Nutrition Activity
Award Description: USAID/Bangladesh intends to award a five-year assistance activity (up to $24.5 million) under the US Government?s Feed the Future (FTF) initiative. This activity, the Feed the Future Bangladesh Aquaculture and Nutrition activity, will improve rural household income and nutrition by increasing aquaculture productivity, strengthening the aquaculture value chain, and improving the awareness and adoption of nutrition related behaviors of rural households. This five-year activity will be comprised of three interrelated components: Component 1: Productivity of Aquaculture Ponds, Component 2: Aquaculture Value Chain, and Component 3: Awareness and Adoption of Nutrition Related Behaviors.

Award Title: NGO Health Service Delivery Activity (NHSDP) Next Iteration
Award Description: NGO Health Service Delivery Activity (NHSDP) Next Iteration

Primary specific objectives include: ? Strengthened nutrition leadership at the national and subnational level for improved multisectoral nutrition service delivery and coordination for accelerated progress in addressing both over and under nutrition. ? Test and demonstrate effective, affordable multisectoral nutrition models, targeting the first 1,000 days. Secondary specific objectives within research sites include: ? Increased access for individuals/households to affordable nutritious food, clean water, sanitation, healthcare and social protection; ? Increased adoption of practices that contribute to good nutrition such as increased consumption of diverse, nutrient dense foods, and exclusive breastfeeding in the first six months of life.

The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) / Bangladesh intends to award a five-year cooperative agreement of up to $10 million. The purpose of the award is to generate demand for and increase use of high quality maternal, neonatal, child and adolescent health (MNCAH), family planning (FP), nutrition, and tuberculosis (TB) services in Bangladesh through the use of social and behavior change communication (SBCC). This SBCC Activity is comprised of two objectives: 1. Increase exposure to and coverage of information on healthy behaviors, services, and health products. 2. Strengthen the Government of Bangladesh Ministry of Health and Family Welfare?s (MoHFW) ability to plan, develop, implement and evaluate effective social and behavior change communication.

Award Title: Strengthening Political Landscape (SPL). Consensus Building with Political Parties
Award Description: USAID/Bangladesh intends to implement a 5-year activity to invest today in leaders, networks and institutions which will be critical in making democracy in Bangladesh more responsive to the needs of the country, more transparent and more inclusive in the future. The Strengthening Political Landscape (SPL) program will support activities that aim to enable political parties to be more inclusive in their internal processes; and to provide political party activists and politically active citizens with the skills to engage constructively to mitigate conflict. The SPL program will be geared towards a future generation of leaders who, when opportunity arises, will be able to respond to requirements of a functional democracy, shaping the political culture that is based on inclusive, responsible and tolerant political practices. The direct beneficiary of the activity is going to be the political parties and politically active citizens of Bangladesh.

Award Title: Facilitating Access to Venture Funding in Belarus (AID-VENTURE)
Award Description: The new activity will support an initiative, which will expand access to venture capital for Belarus start-ups. Illustrative interventions include research on the current barriers to venture capital creation and utilization; advocacy and assistance in drafting laws related to start-up activity and venture capital creation and utilization; awareness raising and educational/outreach events for potential venture capitalists; experience exchanges with regional counterparts; building partnerships for venture capitalists through regional venture capital networks; and establishing the foundation for creating and utilizing local seed and angel investments, and venture capital funds.

Award Description: To amplify the effects of its current assistance programs, USAID/BiH is proposing a two-year activity to develop key educational competencies and life skills to foster a knowledge-based economy and advance economic growth. Specifically, Enhancing and Advancing Basic Learning and Education in Bosnia-Herzegovina (ENABLE-BiH) will focus on operationalizing a teaching curriculum for Common Core mathematics proficiencies and creating standards and guidelines for teacher education across all faculties, based on best international practices.

The public component will assist BiH government and public sector counterparts to implement international norms, practices and rules in the areas of trade and export facilitation to meet EU and international requirements and implement market based policies and practices that support private sector growth. The private sector component will assist selected private sectors to adopt EU and international standards and expand their market access.

Under this program, any assistance given to national, subnational and local authorities should be connected to a policy purpose from a climate change adaptation and mitigation perspective. Efforts should be focused to connect national climate change policies to subnational and local interventions.

The purpose of this activity is to improve the competitiveness of rural producers to respond to new and expanding market opportunities. The initiatives designed under this activity are market-led and focus on meeting the expectations of end markets, to ensure sustainability and increased profitability for rural producers and other actors in the selected value chains. The Producers to Market Alliance (PMA) Activity will help close business deals between producers and buyers to increase incomes of small farmers, including women heads of household and members of minority ethnic groups in rural municipalities that are important to achieving a sustainable and inclusive peace in Colombia.

In September 2011, the Egyptian Ministry of Education (MOE) introduced advanced Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education, as part of its formal secondary education system, targeting gifted students who have the desire and aptitude to pursue specialized and advanced levels of science and mathematics to progress on to higher education. To-date, the MOE established nine STEM schools and is planning to establish eighteen more schools by school year 2018/2019. The planned expansion of STEM education in Egypt has already created demand for highly qualified and skilled STEM teachers who have a solid command of English language and demonstrated understanding of STEM concepts. To satisfy the needs of STEM education, USAID/Egypt is planning to fund the implementation of a STEM Teacher Preparation program, which aims at: 1. Providing pre-service teacher candidates with deep content knowledge and the ability to continually refine their STEM pedagogical skills; and 2. Supporting teachers already within the Ministry of Education?s system as they transition from teaching through traditional lecture to project-based and inquiry-based pedagogy. The program will support the expansion and sustainability of STEM education by preparing candidate teachers to deliver STEM curricula, adopt evolving STEM teaching methodologies, and engage in research and innovation, in addition to strengthening STEM in-service professional development programs. Pre-service and in-service teacher education institutions will institutionalize the development and dissemination of new STEM knowledge. USAID/Egypt recognizes that STEM teacher education requires systemic reform that will involve higher education institutions, the Ministries of Education and Higher Education, and STEM schools. Further, excellence in STEM learning involves linking professors, teachers, and students to the global knowledge economy in order to remain relevant in the ever-evolving area of science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

Award Title: APS - Cultural Heritage Tourism in Egypt
Award Description: APS is seeking multiple awards to improve economic competitiveness of Egypt's cultural tourism destinations and increase tourist satisfaction through the improved and sustainable management of cultural heritage destinations. Awards under this APS will continue USAID's focus on supporting appropriate maintenance and site management in the form of accessibility, restoration, conservation, rehabilitation, documentation, interpretation, reuse, security and community development of cultural heritage tourism destinations.

Award Title: Improved Wellbeing and Health Outcomes for OVC in Ethiopia (IWHO)
Award Description: This award will be part of the United States Agency for International Development?s (USAID?s) support to strengthening systems to deliver needed services to Highly Vulnerable children and their families in Ethiopia. The current OVC program, Yekokeb Berhan, which is implemented by Pact, in conjunction with FHI, Child Fund, and 34 local implementing partners is a 5-year cooperative agreement and will end on the coming September 30, 2016. Accordingly, a new mechanism as a follow on to this; and it has been designed to extend the OVC service to the needy beneficiaries and to improve health and wellbeing outcomes for orphans and vulnerable children (OVC) in scale up /priority Woredas of Ethiopia by enabling more OVC to utilize services for improving HIV/AIDS care, health, nutrition, economic security, education, protection, and psychosocial well-being. In this procurement, USAID/Ethiopia seeks to procure another five years OVC program to be implemented from October 2016 ? September 2021.

This program will provide assistance to the Government of Honduras (GOH) and civil society organizations (CSOs) to support more effective and accountable judicial institutions that promote the rule of law, reduce impunity, protect human rights, act transparently, and engage citizens into their policy-making processes. Interventions will target: national and local judicial institutions, including capacity-building of GOH officials; alternate dispute resolution mechanisms; community police; CSOs that engage with and serve as watchdogs over justice and security actors; and policy creators. USAID will support the efforts of these various stakeholders to collaborate in increasing citizen security and reducing homicide levels both nationally and in targeted areas. Interventions will also support Honduran entities that focus on the protection of human rights.

This Annual Program Statement (APS) 2.0 for the India Partnerships Program (IPP) is USAID/India?s invitation to potential Resource Partners. These are private sector businesses (particularly Indian private businesses), foundations, financial institutions, entrepreneurs, investors, philanthropists, and others that can identify and suggest ways to utilize their financial resources to collaborate with USAID/India. This invitation is equally extended to potential public sector partners (e.g., the Government of India, public companies, as well as other bilateral and multilateral donors). The APS is also USAID/India?s invitation to prospective Implementing Partners (e.g., NGOs, private sector concerns, and others) who can engage and work with Resource Partners. USAID/India encourages Indian implementing organizations (for-profit and not-for-profit non-governmental organizations) and non-traditional Indian development partners, to reach out to Resource Partners, Indian or otherwise, and explore ways in which collaboration with USAID/India might help advance shared development goals.

Award Title: Iraq Governance and Performance Accountability Project
Award Description: Activities will advance effective, accountable, and transparent governance in Iraq. The effort will work with the Government of Iraq (GOI) at all levels to better respond to citizen needs by supporting reform initiatives and Iraqi change agents on inclusive governance and public sector transparency, accountability and economy. ?Reform initiatives? includes support to improve service delivery functions, public financial management, and open government initiatives, the pace of which will be dictated by the GOI. This activity will support the GOI and the citizens of Iraq in forming partnerships and collaborative efforts, particularly in light of the ongoing fiscal and security crises, to jointly solve problems. This activity will be infused with the principles of equity, representation, and participation. These principles are required to support efficient, effective, and inclusive governance aimed improving the lives of Iraq?s citizens and advancing political accommodation through the function of service delivery and the transparent, accountable stewardship of public funds.

There will be a significant focus on alternative livelihoods in the northern region of Jordan, specifically in areas highly impacted by Syrian refugees.

USAID/Mali anticipates awarding a $12 million 5-year Agreement to strengthen citizens? role in the improvement of government accountability. This goal will be achieved by 1) strengthening mechanisms of bottom-up social accountability, 2) strengthening CSO partnerships with the government and private sector to develop public policy and advance issues of common interest, and 3) strengthen citizens? understanding of their rights and responsibilities, and feelings of empowerment to engage with government actors. A primary measure of the success of these activities will be the extent to which they contribute to measurably more responsive and accountable service delivery at the sub-national level.

CTIP II will focus on human trafficking to support the ?Four Ps?: 1: Prevention ?Public agencies, local organizations and networks serving as frontlines for promoting awareness of human trafficking, increasing local livelihoods to mitigate unsafe migration and avoiding victimization. 2: Protection ? Judicial, law enforcement, and other relevant public and/or private entities providing counseling, skills-based training, legal support and other measures to empower victims of trafficking. 3: Prosecution ? more effective law enforcement and judicial systems that apply human rights-based standards in protecting victims and penalties for traffickers who victimize the vulnerable; and more effective application of both counter-trafficking and labor laws. 4: Partnership ? Coordination between the local and national government officials, relevant entities, and non-government stakeholders to strengthen combined efforts to combat trafficking.

Award Title: USAID Regional Health Integration to Enhance Services in Eastern Uganda (RHITES-E)
Award Description: The purpose of this activity for Regional Health Integration to Enhance Services in Eastern Uganda (RHITES-E) is to secure services to support the design and implementation of a comprehensive, integrated investment in regional health, HIV/AIDS, and nutrition assistance. The activity will focus on maximizing the impact of the Government of Uganda (GOU), the United States Government (USG), and other investments in health services and systems using a district-based integrated package of quality health, HIV/AIDS, nutrition, and child development services to contribute to significant, measurable, and sustainable impact on the beneficiary population.

Award Title: USAID Regional Health Integration to Enhance Services- ? North, Acholi (RHITES-N, Acholi)

Award Title: USAID Regional Health Integration to Enhance Services- ? North, Lango (RHITES-N, Lango)
Award Description: The purpose of the Regional Health Integration to Enhance Services ? North, Lango (RHITES-N, Lango) contract is to increase the access and utilization of quality health services in the Lango Region of Northern Uganda, developing health systems to sustain these goals. Working through a life-cycle lens, over five years this contract is expected to contribute to measurable improvements in key population-based national health indicators. USAID requires services to strengthen the capacity of Ugandan institutions and communities to increase access to and utilization of quality, integrated health services in the Lango Sub-Region of Northern Uganda in eight districts in Northern Uganda. These include Amolatar, Alebtong, Apac, Dokolo, Kole, Lira, Oyam, and Otuke (Attachment J.15). USAID anticipates an activity cost to range from $30-35 million during a five-year performance period (September 2016-September 2021). The Uganda Bureau of Statistics (UBOS) 2014 population estimate for the target districts is approximately 2.2 million Ugandans, of which as many as 49 percent are below the age of 15 (~1.1 million) and 20 percent are below the age of five (~450,000).

The project proposed is to accelerate sustainable improvement in quality, access and supply of water and sanitation services, and improve hygiene behaviors in Uganda through Increased household access to sanitation and water services; expanded key hygiene behaviors at home, school, and health facilities and Strengthened district water and sanitation governance.

Award Title: Increasing Citizen Demand for Accountable and Transparent Service Delivery in the Health Sector through Enhanced Community-Based Monitoring
Award Description: The project will seek to mobilize communities and increase their engagement in monitoring the delivery of health services. Proposed activities will include enhancing citizens? action based on basic facts on utilization and quality of services collected from the communities themselves. It will include improving upon or developing community-based monitoring tools such as report cards, social contracts, and action plans. This component will seek to strengthen existing local governance social structures such, as the neighborhood health committees, health advisory committees, and/or safe-motherhood action groups. Health service providers under the government will also be involved to improve and strengthen their engagement with community members.

Award Title: Integrating Agriculture, Nutrition and Water and Sanitation Project
Award Description: The Economic Development, Health and Education Offices propose a jointly-managed integrated agriculture, nutrition, and water and sanitation activity to reduce stunting through agricultural, water and sanitation and behavior change pathways in targeted districts of Zambia. The expected geographic focus will be in Eastern Province, potentially with selected districts in Central or Muchinga Provinces. Addressing stunting requires children and pregnant and lactating women are consuming adequate quantity, quality and diversity of food and that adequate health conditions exist for them to biologically utilize what they eat. This requires a complexity of interventions that increase access and availability of safe, diverse, nutritious food (usually relying on home production), adoption of better child feeding and women?s diets, water and hygiene practices to improve food safety and utilization, and access to clean water and a healthier, cleaner environment. This requires a multi-sectoral approach that increases incomes; improves agricultural productivity and private sector led value chain development in nutrient-dense, protein-rich foods; improves access to and availability and utilization of nutritious food, clean water, and sanitation; improves health-seeking behaviors for both the pregnant mother, as well as her child; and promotes essential nutrition and hygiene behaviors, including hand-washing, exclusive breastfeeding, appropriate complementary feeding, child spacing, and hygienic play spaces. The selected agricultural value chains should build on current Feed the Future programs and would likely choose from groundnuts, soy, cowpea, pigeon pea, orange maize, orange flesh sweet potato, African Indigenous Vegetables, and poultry, to ensure a source of protein. The water and sanitation activities should build on lessons learned from previous USAID WASH programming, promote access to and use of latrines at household level, and safe water points, CLTS and Essential Hygiene Actions and most critically, strengthen governance and private sector engagement to ensure long-term sustainability, potentially building on foundations laid in previous USAID-funded SPLASH communities. Direct nutrition interventions at households and nutrition-sensitive messaging across all sectors will be critical to the success of the project. The project will incorporate strong learning components, potentially with embedded operations and/or other evaluation approaches to address research gaps and generate lessons learned about approaches to integration.

Assist the Ministry of Education to provide textbooks and learning materials in the seven local languages and English for primary school children; teachers' professional development particularly in the area of reading pedagogy and instruction; and conducting testing and reading assessments at the school level.

M/B/IO: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance (DCHA)
Award Description: The purpose of this award is to provide technical assistance and advisory services, training, and direct program implementation to support good governance, transparency, and accountability in host countries. This award is designed to foster greater accountability of institutions and leaders to citizens and to the law by strengthening linkages among government actors and enhancing state institutions accountability to citizens. The activities implemented under this award will contribute directly to the achievement of the overarching goal of USAID's Strategy on Democracy, Human Rights and Governance, which is to support the establishment and consolidation of inclusive and accountable democracies to advance freedom and development. This award will enable Missions which issue task orders under it to select from a range of programming options. In addition, the award will enable USAID and the U.S. Government (USG) to respond rapidly to windows of opportunity for governance in countries undergoing transition.

M/B/IO: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance (DCHA)
Award Description: The Analytical Services IV IDIQ will directly build on USAID?s DRG Strategy by providing support to USAID Missions and other operating units to develop strategies and projects that will have the greatest impact. Ultimately, USAID strategies and programs that are based on sound analysis are more likely to be effective. Missions will be able to quickly and efficiently commission analyses, access expert assistance, and obtain other services in support of strategic planning, policy analysis and development, and project design. The IDIQ will allow the DRG Center to continue to conduct and support DRG sector and sub-sector assessments, political economy analyses, inclusive development analysis ? on gender, disabilities, LGBT, youth, indigenous, etc. -- and other strategic planning priorities
Implementing Partner: Social Impact ARD Incorporated Management Systems International (MSI) Democracy International Incorporated International Resources Group (IRG)

M/B/IO: Bureau for Democracy, Conflict and Humanitarian Assistance (DCHA)
Award Description: New phase of the Famine Early Warning Systems Network, FEWS NET.   The Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET) provides objective, evidence-based analysis to help the U.S. Government (USG), national and international partners, and relief agencies plan and respond to food security crises and mitigate human suffering.  FEWS NET and its precursor activity, the Famine Early Warning System (FEWS) have operated for more than 30 years. Initially established in the Sahelian region of Africa as a response to the 1984/85 famines, FEWS gradually expanded over the three decades to cover countries in East, West and Southern Africa, as well as parts of Central America and the Caribbean, Middle East, and Central Asia. The project currently has offices in approximately 25 countries, with remote coverage of food security in an additional 10 countries.

Award Title: Sustainable WASH Systems (SWS) Broad agency Announcement (BAA)
Award Description: Sustainable WASH Systems (SWS) Broad agency Announcement (BAA)

This is a Broad Agency Announcement (BAA) and is not tied to any funding. The addenda that are issued under this BAA may have funding tied to it. The total estimated cost/amount range is $0 for the BAA itself.

CTP is seeking communication, technical and institutional support services to advance private sector engagement and facilitation of public-private partnership building. The contractor shall provide services on an as needed basis as to CTP, other USAID Washington operating units and USAID Missions globally. BPA via GSA PSS schedule.
E&E is seeking an Empirical Analyst, PSC to support the SPA division in working with the MCP's partnership at the Department of State's, Office of U.S. Foreign Assistance Resources (F).

E&E is seeking an Environmental Officer, PSC to provide supplementary professional support, training, compliance auditing, compliance evaluations, and regional coordination on 22 CFR 216 matters to Mission Directors, Teams, Activity Managers, or contract/agreement officer representatives, and Mission Environmental Officers (MEOs).
